entry.title: Re: Error 500 in CAP entitySet READ
entry.content:
@MioYasutake  Thank you for your reply.

My application.yaml was automatically generated with the same content as yours. So maybe it shouldn't be the issue here.

I later tried some other methods to fix the error mentioned above. Finally, I resolved it using the approach below (at least that error no longer appears, though I don't understand why). But thank you very much anyway.

I modified the structure/writing style of my .cds file.

Before:

service My_SRV {
    entity MoeSet as projection on TestSet;
}

entity TestSet {
    key testKey : String(64);
    inputData : String(100);
    memo: String(100);
    outputData: String(100);
}

 

After:

service My_SRV {
    entity TestSet {
		key testKey : String(64);
		inputData : String(100);
		memo: String(100);
		outputData: String(100);
    }
}

entry.title: Get information of actual parameters
entry.content:
Hi,

is it possible to retrieve information of actual parameters (arguments) in ABAP?

In my use case I want to know the identifier of the passed actual parameter of a method call.

Example:

...
METHODS do_anything
  IMPORTING
    parameter TYPE string.

...

METHOD do_anything
  DATA(name_of_actual_parameter) = get_name_actual_parameter( parameter ).
  " name_of_actual_parameter should contain as value my_variable
ENDMETHOD.

...

DATA my_variable TYPE string.
do_anything( parameter = my_variable ).

BR

entry.title: SAP CS to S4HANA Service - End of Usage Right vs. Display Transactions in 2030+
entry.content:
SAP brought SAP CS as Compatibility Pack to S4HANA and informed in notes 2962632 and 2269324 that the product is discontinued with SAP S4HANA Service as successor as well as usage rights ends by 31/12/30.

Furthermore, there's a nice blog article describing what happens and how to move on.
A crucial topic ("Can documents and transactional data in Compatibility Scope still be displayed and can open business processes be finished?") is handled in chapter 8: can I access in read mode to my legacy data.

Though there's a general statement (I conclude reading access might still be possible since PM functionality will stay), it's referencing to the related Business Impact Note. As per "S4HANA CompScope - Way Forward - Info" Excel sheet, the respective note is again 2962632. There's no statement for the read-possibilities.

Is there any official statement confirming there is still read access to CS Service Orders/Notification beyond 2030 (without need to extract data to 3rd party solutions or pull the data in customer specific reports)?

 

Thank you very much!

entry.title: Re: Project-Based Services in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hey there!

Great question‚Äîthis is a classic SAP nuance that's tripped me up too. You're spot on: freight charges use the "Stock" checkbox to decide capitalization (adding to item cost via WIP) or expensing, but the expense clearing account is still needed for the journal entry balance during GRPO. It's not a direct expense post; it's an offset that reverses on inventory issue. For landed costs, it's more streamlined via the distribution rule in the landed cost document, without the checkbox‚Äîcosts hit a clearing account first, then settle to inventory or COGS. The key difference is freight's line-level control vs. landed's document-level allocation.

For quick freight cost estimates in projects, I use kalkulatorpaliwa.com.pl to model scenarios before SAP entries‚Äîit helps spot variances early. Have you tried configuring OBYC for the clearing account yet, or is the DIP profile the bigger headache? Happy to brainstorm more!

Hi everybody, we are heading into the final week of Devtoberfest. This blog post should give you a good overview on what is happening in our second week of Devtoberfest.

Sessions for Week 4 (Oct 20 - Oct 24):

All sessions for Week 4 can be found in our Session Catalogue: https://community.sap.com/t5/devtoberfest/eb-p/devtoberfest-events

entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (1/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP standard production orders information system, the COOIS transaction, is a very powerful and flexible tool to report various aspects of production and planned orders. It can be easily customized and enhanced.

The COHV transaction couples COOIS with order mass processing functions enhancing the PP information system even further. It provides various mass processing functions like order release, staging, costing, etc.

The note 1819470 - Mass processing functions are missing in t-code COHV has introduced two additional options to fix/delete fixing and to delete planned orders. The note shows that the mass processing capabilities of COHV can be enhanced. However, I have not been able to find any official extension points or documentation on how to add customer defined functions to COHV. This article is meant to close this gap and to present step-by-step instructions to implement new mass processing functions.

 

Enhance fixed values list of CO_FUNCT domain

The mass processing function list is defined with a reference to CO_FUNCT data element.

Figure 1: Technical details of the "Function" field in COHV

The data element refers to the CO_FUNCT domain.

Figure 2: The CO_FUNCT data element details

The list of mass processing functions available in COHV is defined with fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain. Notice that the list has already been enhanced with 205 and 215 functions delivered with the note 1819470 - Mass processing functions are missing in t-code COHV

Figure 3: The fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain

Therefore, the first step is to add a custom function code to the fixed values of the domain. The exact procedure is described on SAP Help: Creating Fixed Value Appends 

Figure 4: The fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain enhanced with a custom function

 

Register the custom function

The next step is to register the custom function with COHV. That is done in the include LCOWORKF06, the FORM routine REGISTERED_FUNCTIONS_INIT

SAP provides the enhancement spot ES_SAPLCOWORK to register additional functions. However, it is for SAP internal use only. Unfortunately, there are no standard enhancements available here either. Therefore, I am going to use implicit enhancement at the end of the routine.

The fct_icon field is optional, but it is a nice touch to have an icon assigned to the mass processing function.

 

Add the custom function in the COISL transaction

Finally, the custom function needs to be assigned to order information list type in the COISL transaction.

 

Final result

The final result is that the custom function is visible and selectable in COHV.

Figure 5: The custom function in the COHV initial screen

 It is also available as a push button with the icon assigned in the registration step in the COHV toolbar.

Figure 6: The custom function in the COHV toolbar

The custom function is also visible and executable from the COHV results list. 

Naturally, the custom function does not do anything for now. The function execution implementation is the topic of the next episode. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

entry.title: Identity and Access Management with Microsoft Entra, Part III: SuccessFactors and Role Provisioning
entry.content:
Scenario Overview

Part III introduces substantial changes and enhancements to the scenario in part II:

  • Microsoft Entra and Active Directory (AD) were the primary and authoritative systems (aka "source of authority", SOA) for identity data in part II. For many organizations, however, the trusted SOA for identities is a Human Resource Information System (HRIS) such as SAP SuccessFactors (SF), which will be added to the scenario in this part, and where new employees are now onboarded.
  • Identity creation, updates, and deprovisioning are now driven by HR events (e.g., hiring, role changes, terminations) from SF. AD and Entra become downstream provisioning targets in this scenario. Because users require access to SAP from SAP GUI on their corporate AD domain-joined workstation using Kerberos/SNC-based single sign-on (SSO, see part II), the solution architecture in this scenario integrates SF with the SAP SuccessFactors to Active Directory user provisioning connector from the Microsoft Entra App Gallery. This pre-built, cloud-based solution supports inbound- or HR-driven provisioning of new employees from SF to AD through Entra. New users provisioned to AD by this connector will be synchronized to Entra with the existing setup of the Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync Provisioning Agent from part II of this blog series that runs on the Domain Controller (DC) in our fictitious company BestRun's corporate network.
  • Part II focused on the automation of provisioning the user's identity data. The user's authorization in the SAP backend (we used role SAP_BC_ABAP_DEVELOPER_5 as an example) was still managed manually by assigning the user to the equally named group "SAP_BC_ABAP_DEVELOPER_5" in the CIS tenant (see step 10.20 in part II). Also the group in CIS had to be created manually in the previous part of the scenario (see steps 9.17-9.19). This approach may work for a few backend authorizations, but won't scale for a larger number of connected systems and applications with complex authorization models. A key objective in this scenario is to fully automate end-to-end provisioning and deprovisioning of the user's authorizations, which includes the synchronization of backend roles and their corresponding groups in CIS and Entra, as well as the memberships of users to these groups, that ultimately assigns them to the backend roles. The updated version of the SAP CIS connector from the Microsoft Entra App Galley now enables automated provisioning entitlements as groups and their memberships from Entra to CIS. This new feature in the SCIM (System for Cross-domain Identity Management, IETF RFCs 7642, 7643 and 7644)-compliant outbound provisioning connector in Entra streamlines the end-to-end lifecycle management for authorizations in the scenario. By assigning the new user to a group representing the PFCG role in the SAP ABAP system, this group and the user's membership are now also automatically provisioned to CIS, and from there to the backend system. Similar to part II, the group in Entra and CIS is mapped to the PFCG role by using the same name.

Figure 1 illustrates the SOA for the IAM entities in the scenario:

Figure 1

 

Although SOA for identity data moves to SF, the connected SAP system remains the authority for the definition of the roles that can be assigned in the scenario. Managing the actual assignment of users to these roles through access packages and approval workflows remains the responsibility of Entra ID Governance. With no single SOA for users, groups and roles centralized at one place in the system landscape, figure 1 shows the updated and newly introduced system components based on the existing setup from part II, and illustrates the steps of the provisioning flow for a new onboarded employee requesting access to a role in the corporate SAP system:

 

Figure 2

 

 

 

  1. CIS is responsible to integrate the connected SAP systems following this reference architecture. It synchronizes the role from the backend (SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO in this scenario) with the SAP Application Server ABAP connector configured as a Source System in BestRun's CIS tenant Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) which results in creating a group with the same name in the tenant's local directory. Connectivity from CIS to the SAP system on-premises remains unchanged from part II and is established via the connectivity service in BTP and the SAP Cloud Connector deployed in the corporate network.
  2. CIS also takes care for creating the group in Entra by provisioning it with the Entra ID connector configured as a target system in the CIS tenant. This connector uses the Microsoft Graph API to manage groups in Entra.
  3. The HR admin adds a new employee record in SF for the user in the sceanrio, Linda Larson. 
  4. The SAP SuccessFactors to Active Directory user provisioning connector picks up the new employee record by calling the SF Employee Central OData API endpoints to query for new or updated data.
  5. The connector then provisions a user account for the new employee Linda in BestRun's corporate AD via Entra Cloud Sync and the Entra Provisioning Agent on the DC.
  6. With Entra Cloud Sync configured in part II to synchronize AD with the Entra tenant, the new account in the corporate AD is also provisioned to BestRun's Entra ID tenant.
  7. Linda starts a request for the SAP EPM access package with the MyAccess portal. For this initial login to Entra, Linda can use the self-service password reset (SSPR) feature in Entra to set her new Entra user account's password. With password writeback enabled in Entra Cloud Sync and SSPR to use password writeback, Linda's initial password reset or any future changes of her password are synchronized back to BestRun's on-premises AD as well. By completing the request, Linda is assigned to the access package resources, and becomes a member in the SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO group in Entra. To keep things simple, the access package policy requires no approval steps in this scenario.
  8. The SAP CIS connector enterprise app is configured to perform all operations (create/update/delete) on new or existing user objects, but to skip creation on groups. Otherwise, Entra would try to create the same group again in CIS that has already been created in step 1, which would result in a naming conflict. Instead, it creates a new user account for Linda in CIS, but only updates her membership to the SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO group in BestRun's CIS tenant.
    In addition to the new support for groups in the new version of the SAP CIS connector, authentication to CIS no longer uses basic authentication that sends static credentials with every request. Instead, short‚Äëlived tokens with scoped, limited privileges using the OAuth 2.0 client credentials grant flow enhance security over basic authentication.
  9. Provisioning to the SAP backend with the already existing SAP Application Server ABAP connector configured as a Target System in IPS starts by reading the new user and her group membership from the CIS tenant's local directory, and creating the new user in SAP as well as assigning this user to the corresponding SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO role.
  10. Finally, Linda can login to BestRun's corporate AD from her workstation, obtains a Kerberos token from the DC, and uses it to securely single sign-on to the backend from SAP GUI and the SAP Secure Login Client. This requires mapping of her user principal name (UPN) in AD to her SAP user, which has already been configured in the mappings of the SAP CIS connector in Entra (see step 6.18 in part II) and the transformation of the SAP Application Server ABAP target system in IPS (see step 9.12 in part II).

Prerequisites and lab setup

You can continue to use all subscriptions, systems and tenants from your lab in part II, because all prerequisites also apply for this scenario. In addition, make sure that you meet the following prerequisites to successfully implement the enhanced scope of this scenario:

  • Administrative access to an SF instance with permissions to setup provisioning credentials and onboard new employees.
  • An SCI tenant in a matching region of your BTP subaccount for on-premise connectivity that has Microsoft Entra ID as a target system enabled.
  • An Entra ID tenant with self-service password reset (SSPR) enabled and Entra Connect cloud sync configured for SSPR writeback to the AD in the scenario.
  • Re-run steps 9.1 to 9.10 of part II in your CIS tenatn with the updated file LocalDirectory.json for the LocalDirectory source system, and the updated file SAPA4H_IPS.json for the SAPA4H target system. The updated files apply minor changes to the transformations of both systems based on valuable feedback in the comments to part II. The customAttributes are no longer used to carry over the values for the SAP user name and SNC mapping from Entra to CIS. Instead, the extension attribute sapUserName is used, and construction of the SNC mapping has moved from Entra to the transformation of the SAPA4H target systems (lines 13 to 28).
Note üì¢üì¢üì¢

This tutorial extends and updates the scenario from part II. Any components and their configurations that are not added or changed in this scenario, such as the SAP Cloud Connector or Active Directory, are not covered in this tutorial. If you arrived here and have not completed part II, please do so first, and then come back again.

As before, supporting files for this tutorial can be found in the blog series GitHub repository. Now let's get started with setting up the provisioning of new employees from SAP SuccessFactors to Entra.

The Entra attribute "onPremisesUserPrincipalName" added in step 3.9 has the format "<Windows user name>@<Kerberos realm name>". The SAP login name should be equal to the Windows user name that can be considered unique across all users in the organization.

The following expression extracts the Windows user name from the "onPremisesUserPrincipalName" and converts it to upper case for the SAP login name:

Item(Split([onPremisesUserPrincipalName], "@"), 1)

Enter this string for the Expression.

entry.title: Clarification on MRP Behaviour for Split Procurement Between Supplying Plant and External Vendor
entry.content:
Dear Support Team,

We have a coming demo for a customer which they particularly asked for few scenarios. I would like to seek clarification on the one of the MRP scenario involving two plants.

Scenario:

  • Plant A ‚Äì Requirement is created through a weekly PIR for a raw material.

  • Plant B ‚Äì Acts as the supplying plant with no demand of its own but has stock available to supply Plant A.

  • In Plant A, the material master is maintained with a Special Procurement Key to source from Plant B.

Expectation:

  1. When MRP runs in Plant A, it should create a Stock Transport Requisition (STO) from Plant B to cover the PIR demand.

  2. Later, if Plant B does not have enough stock available, and the PIR quantity in Plant A is increased, the next MRP run in Plant A should:

    • Create an STO for the quantity available in Plant B, and

    • Create an external Purchase Requisition for the remaining shortage, which Plant B cannot fulfil.

Question:
Does MRP in Plant A check the stock availability in Plant B before generating procurement proposals? If Plant B only has partial stock, can the system automatically generate an STO for the available quantity and an external PR for the remaining requirement within the same MRP run? Or will it continue to create only the STO as per the special procurement setup?

I understand that a possible workaround could be to use Quota Management to manage multiple sources of supply. However, this option is not feasible in this case, as the customer does not wish to use quota arrangements for this scenario.

Please confirm if the expected split procurement behaviour is supported in standard SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, or if an enhancement or specific configuration is required to achieve it.

Best regards,
Vindhya

entry.title: Integration from IS-H to SAP Health Data Services for FHIR: Check Out the New Guide!
entry.content:
Ever thought about trying out FHIR messaging in an SAP setup? Or maybe pushing some IS-H data over to SAP Health Data Services for FHIR for something specific? If that's a "yes," then our new guide is just what you need! It walks you through integrating SAP Patient Management (IS-H) with SAP Health Data Services for FHIR.

What's in it for IS-H Customers?

If you're using IS-H, this guide comes in handy for a bunch of reasons:

  • All-in-One Integration Help: Get all the info you need to plug into the SAP ecosystem smoothly, especially SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP, so things flow nicely.
  • More Use Cases Unlocked: Check out different scenarios, like moving selected IS-H data into SAP‚Äôs FHIR server ‚Äì SAP Health Data Services for FHIR. It‚Äôs perfect for building cool new apps or storing data during a migration.
  • Get to Know FHIR Messaging: It facilitates familiarization with FHIR messaging from both sides, the IS-H FHIR framework side and the SAP Health Data Services for FHIR side.

Even if you‚Äôre not using IS-H, this guide still works as a blueprint to hook up any EMR system to SAP Health Data Services for FHIR.

 

What Can You Really Expect from This Guide?

  • Developer's View: A solid overview for developers wanting to integrate IS-H with SAP Health Data Services for FHIR using FHIR messaging.
  • Intro to FHIR Messaging: The guide includes an easy-to-understand introduction to FHIR messaging.
  • How to Configure: Covers the setup you need for both SAP Health Data Services for FHIR and SAP Patient Management, like setting up technical users, defining message events, and configuring messaging.
  • Message Tweaks: Tips on dealing with message generation using Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) on the IS-H side. Plus, instructions to keep configurations in check, like business events and patient profiles, and how to set up FHIR packages right in the SAP Health Data Services for FHIR instance.
  • Step-by-Step Guidance: Answers to your burning questions about integration, configuration, and implementation, with easy, step-by-step advice and error-handling tricks.

You can grab the full guide here for IS-H 618 and here for IS-H 617.

Oh, and remember my earlier blog ‚ÄúIntegrating EMR Systems with SAP S/4HANA Cloud‚Äù. This new guide ties in perfectly, helping you kick off the initial steps outlined in the video.

entry.title: Part 1 - Boost Your ABAP Productivity with Joule: Explain & detect Test Dependencies
entry.content:
Hello folks,

Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities in SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP BTP ABAP Environment is technically available in all development tenants since release 2502. Follow the note 3571857  to know the pre-requisites to have the Joule capabilities in your IDE.

Joule currently supports three powerful AI-assisted actions directly inside ADT / IDE:


ExplainUnderstand the code instantly
Find Test-Unfriendly DependenciesIdentify interfaces, DB objects, or classes blocking unit testability
Generate Unit Tests (AUnits)Auto-create ABAP test classes with mocks and test case
 
All these capabilities are very useful unless you know how to really provide the context into the Joule. Let‚Äôs understand them one by one.

This series of blog is constitutes of two parts:

  1. Explain and Find Test-Unfriendly dependencies
  2. Generate Unit Tests(Aunits)

Let's look at the capability(1) - "Explain" 

There are some ways to do so. Let‚Äôs try each and see the differences. I have created a demo class for demonstrating the Joule capabilities in IDE.

Approach 1 - Right-click on method name in project explorer‚Üí Joule ‚Üí Explain 

Since at this point, Joule can only read the parameters of the method, it is not giving very useful info about the method.

Hmm, what else we can do to provide more context to Joule?

Yes, there is a way!

Approach 2 - Select the implementation of the code ‚Üí Right-click ‚ÜíJoule ‚Üí Explain 

As the selected code has the given the context to Joule to read the code, Joule explains it very easily.

What‚Äôs next? Can we know more about the method in detail? Yes we can and we have 2 options for it‚Äì

You can click any of it and this will give you more explanation.

Like I selected explain in more detail.

Now Joule is even more technical, it is explaining code, method signature, technical explanation and finally the conclusion.

Let‚Äôs see how the capability(2) - "Test-Unfriendly dependencies" work with the help of Joule.

This capability helps you to prepare the code for unit testing by listing external dependencies like interfaces, CDS views, database tables, or classes. Let's see the steps below:

Step1 - Right-click on the class ‚Üí Joule ‚Üí Start Chat for AUnits


Step 2 - Click on Find Test-Unfriendly Dependencies

Click on Find Test-Unfriendly Dependencies and Joule will list all the Test-Unfriendly dependencies like interfaces, database objects (CDS, tables), classes etc.

In this case, this class is dependent on an interface. You can click on the list and Joule will navigate you to the source code where the dependent object is used.

This brings to the one of the most powerful capabilities(3)  - "Generate Unit Tests".

It is covered in the next part of the blog.

Note - There is no standard way of doing this activity, this is my tried and tested way for enriching the code context to Joule and it does a good job. Always make sure to review any generated code or suggestion to finally use in your code.

entry.title: Part 2 - Boost Your ABAP Productivity with Joule: Generate Unit Tests(AUnits)
entry.content:
Hello enthusiasts, 

The series of blog is constitutes of two parts:

  1. Explain and Find Test-Unfriendly dependencies
  2. Generate Unit Tests(Aunits)

As explained in the part-1 of the blog, Joule currently supports three powerful AI-assisted actions directly inside ADT / IDE:


ExplainUnderstand the code instantly
Find Test-Unfriendly DependenciesIdentify interfaces, DB objects, or classes blocking unit testability
Generate Unit Tests (AUnits)Auto-create ABAP test classes with mocks and test case

This is the part-2 of the blog series, here we are going to understand  one of the most powerful capabilities of Joule in IDE - "Generate Unit Tests".

There are some ways to generate the ABAP Units, Let‚Äôs looks at them one-by-one.

Approach 1 - Do a right click on the method you want to generate the Aunit and Joule will propose the Aunit code.

Joule has proposed 2 test methods ‚Äì Check_m1_valid_data and Check_m1_empty_result

The code is comparing the result with ‚ÄúValid Result‚Äô and we don‚Äôt even have it in our method Check_M1 and the reason  is - Joule does not have the context of the implementation code of CHECK_M1.

Let‚Äôs do with the second way.

Approach B - Select the implementation code and ask Joule to explain the code.

This gives the Joule the context about the code and now it becomes better to write Aunits.

Ask to explain in more details like we did in the previous part of the blog.

Give the prompt ‚Äì Find test-unfriendly dependencies of this method.

Give the prompt to Joule - Generate the ABAP unit for this method with the help of test doubles for the test-unfriendly dependencies.

Here, we go!

Joule has identified mi_data and /ape/if_proc_data~get_proc_data as dependencies.

This is the real power of Joule, it has not just created test methods to cover ‚ÄúPassed‚Äù and ‚Äúfailed‚Äù cases but also has done an incredible job to create mock data for mi_data.

So, the key is ‚Äì

  1. Select the code and ask Joule to explain.
  2. Ask to find test dependencies like -   find the test-dependencies of the method check_determine_counter
  3. And then ask Joule to write AUNIT taking test doubles into consideration for the test-dependencies.

Note - There is no standard way of doing this activity, this is my tried and tested way for enriching the code context to Joule and it does a good job. Always make sure to review any generated code or suggestion to finally use in your code.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Goods Receipt Cancellation...
entry.content:
Hello @byd,

Here is what are standard in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for cancelling goods receipts (GR) and what you should do for payment recovery and timing.

Standard: GR cancellation reverses logistics and accounting, timed by posting date and open periods, corrected with Supplier Credit Memo, tracked in GR/IR apps. SAP Help Portal-Material Documents Overview

Not standard: auto-comparing historic payments versus cancellation amounts and auto-creating incoming/outgoing payments. Would require process and workflow design

Automatic reversal when you cancel a GR

Yes. Cancelling a material document creates a reversal material document and the related accounting reversal stock or consumption, and GR/IR where relevant. Do this from the material document Cancel or Reverse or via the Fiori apps for material documents. SAP Help Portal-Material Documents Overview

Note: If no supplier invoice exists yet, the GR/IR effect is fully reversed by the cancellation itself. If an invoice already exists or was even paid, the GR cancellation does not auto-reverse Accounts Payable. SAP Help Portal-Clear GR/IR Clearing Account

Handling payment vs. cancellation amount

Not automatic. The system does not auto-compare prior payments with the GR cancellation and generate incoming and outgoing payments.

If a supplier invoice exists and must be reduced or refunded, post a Supplier Credit Memo reference the PO/material document where possible. Payment program will net it against open items; if already paid, the credit memo creates the receivable to recover from the supplier. SAP Help Portal-Creating Supplier Invoices and Credit Memos

If goods physically go back, use Return to Supplier and then post or receive the supplier credit memo that follows the return. SAP Help Portal-Return to Supplier

Posting period and timing options for the reversal

When you cancel, you control the posting date of the reversal subject to open periods. 

You can post in the current open period typical or Back-date into the original month if that period is still open.
Period control is via Open and Close Posting Periods (Finance) and Close Periods  and Manage Posting Periods for Materials. There isn‚Äôt a force into original month if closed option,closed periods block back-posting.  SAP Help Portal-Opening and Closing Posting Periods

Recovery when the vendor owes you after GR cancellation

Use Supplier Credit Memo in Manage/Create Supplier Invoices (with PO reference where possible) to document the vendor‚Äôs refund obligation and track it in AP open items and reporting.SAP Learning-Performing a supplier Returns in SAP

Useful paths (Public Cloud)

  • Material Documents Overview ‚Üí Open GR ‚Üí Cancel or Reverse. SAP Help Portal
  • Display Cancel Material Documents (library entry shows reversal behavior). Material Documents Overview
  • Manage Create Supplier Invoices (create Credit Memo). SAP Help-Creating Supplier Invoices and Credit Memos
  • Return to Supplier (process guide). SAP Help Portal and SAP Learning-Performing a supplier Returns in SAP
  • Open and Close Posting Periods (Finance) and Close Manage Posting Periods (Materials). SAP Help Portal-Opening and Closing Posting Period

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Accounts Payable Functiona...
entry.content:
Hello @byd 

Thank you for your question.

To summarise, all the listed AP functionalities are available in standard public cloud. An exception is for minor extensions in integration detail or data enrichment for special regulatory cases. Find the explanations below:

  1. Automatic AP Posting can be done through standard GR/IR clearing, evaluated receipt settlement (ERS), and workflow-based supplier invoices.
  2. Payment Scheduling & Cash Flow is covered by Cash Flow Analyser, Liquidity Forecast, and Manage Payments.
  3. Due Date Change Tracking is standardly done through change longs in supplier invoices.
  4. External Integrations can be achieved through Payment Request API, Concur, and Bank Communication Management.
  5. Overseas Remittance Compliance is supported through ISO20022 payment formats and Payment Medium Workbench.
  6. Payment Hold Management is available in the payment block tracking, overdue payable analysis, and Situation Handling alerts.
  7. Have a look at the following references for more details.

The following references provide further details:

Accounts Payable Overview

Manage Automatic Payments

Liquidity Forecast

Payments and Bank Communication in S/4HANA Cloud

Overdue Payables

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Creating a personal development environment #4 - A custom theme for SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Creating a personal development environment #4 - A custom theme for SAP TechEd 2025

  1. #1 - Why Neovim?
  2. #2 - Miscellaneous, status line, and color scheme
  3. #3 - Vim keybindings
  4. #4 - A custom theme for SAP TechEd 2025 (this blog post)

Building on top of the previous three blog posts, this blog post will focus on creating a custom theme for Neovim, inspired by the SAP TechEd 2025 branding.

I always enjoy playing around with themes in editors and the SAP TechEd branding was the perfect blueprint to work on a real custom theme for Neovim for the first time. I had previously only changed a few colors in existing themes or applied background images via local config files, but never created a full theme that also others could actually use. So let's get started.

At first, I inspected the documentation of my beloved carbonfox by nightfox.nvim theme to remind myself of how to extend it. I played with a few colors that I got from the SAP TechEd templates and added them to the plugin configuration of the existing theme (~/.config/nvim/lua/plugins/theme.lua), which looked something like this:

return {
    "EdenEast/nightfox.nvim",
    config = function()
        require("nightfox").setup({
            options = {
                palettes = {
                    carbonfox = {
                        bg0  = "#89D1FF", -- Dark bg (status line and float)
                        bg1  = "#EBF8FF", -- Default bg
                        sel0 = "#FF8AF0", -- Popup bg, visual selection bg                    
                        sel1 = "#FFCC00", -- Popup sel bg, search bg}
                    }
                },
                transparent = true,
                styles = {
                    comments = "italic"
                }
            }
        })
        vim.cmd "colorscheme carbonfox"
    end
}

I then realized that there had to be more to it than just changing the colors of the existing palette, as a palette contains not as many colors (16) as the theme actually uses and provides (32). I noticed that because the theme also provides config files for many terminals to copy and paste into your terminal settings (for example this kitty.conf), so that your terminal and Neovim are fully in sync - and those config files had other colors in them that where not part of the palette, plus the names of the colors in the palette did not match the ones on the config file. So now I had to understand how bg0 becomes active_tab_foreground and so on. There was probably some build step with additional logic happening here. After some digging and reverse-engineering, I came up with a mapping that allowed me to test a certain color in both my terminal and Neovim, as I now knew which color in the palette would later become which color in the terminal config:

comment
    inactive_tab_foreground

bg0
    active_tab_foreground

bg1
    background
    cursor_text_color

bg4
    inactive_border_color

fg1
    cursor none
    selection_foreground
    foreground

sel0
    selection_background
    inactive_tab_background

black
    color0

red
    color1

green
    color2
    url_color

yellow
    color3

blue
    color4
    active_border_color
    active_tab_background

magenta
    color5

cyan
    color6

white
    color7

orange
    color16
    bell_border_color 

pink
    color17

After a few iterations of tweaking colors and testing them in both Neovim and my terminal, I finally arrived at a color scheme that I liked and that resembled the SAP TechEd branding quite well. To make it easier for others to use it as well, I forked the nightfox.nvim repo and added the colors to two new themes: saptechedlightfox and saptecheddarkfox. You can find the fork on my GitHub. While digging into the repo, I found that (as already suspected) the terminal config files are generated during a build step and that there is logic in place to transform a few colors to get different shades for them. You can find these files in the extra/ directory of the repo.

The new themes can now be applied to Neovim like this (notice the module now pointing to my fork):

return {
    "nicoschoenteich/nightfox.nvim",
    config = function()
        require("nightfox").setup({
            options = {
                transparent = true,
                styles = {
                    comments = "italic"
                }
            }
        })
        vim.cmd "colorscheme saptechedlightfox"
    end
}

If you also want to apply the background image (see screenshots below), you can find in the extra/ directory of the forked repo and apply them to your terminal of choice. This is what the config looks like for kitty:

...
window_logo_path background-light.png
window_logo_position bottom-right
window_logo_alpha 1
window_logo_scale 100
...

I will close this blog post with a few screenshots of the final result:

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Accounts Receivable Functi...
entry.content:
Hello @byd 

Thank you for your question.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, the following applies for your AR-related requirements:

1 Customer Acceptance Reconciliation - not standard implement via SAP BTP or API-based custom process.

2 AR/AP Offset for Same BP - standard when the same BP has both AR & AP roles; manual clearing otherwise.

3 Refund for Negative AR Balances - fully supported in standard, with BCM integration and ISO20022 payment formats

4 Aging Receivables Management - standard Fiori analytical apps (F0736, F1511, F2217) cover this comprehensively.

Only requirement #1 would require a custom integration or extension. All others are standard and available in Public Cloud scope..

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Accounts Receivable Overview

Manage Automatic Payments

Aging Analysis

Situation Handling

Do not hesitate to reach out if you have further questions.

Best regards 

Chris

entry.title: Re: Queue Display not supported for function /SCWM/QDECID...
entry.content:
Hi Raghavan,
I understand you have try to analyze the error but still you don't know what is missing.
You can do some additional checks as suggested below.


1. Check if the queue is stuck or inactive: Go to SMQ2 and verify the status of the LUW (Logical Unit of Work). If it's in "Ready" or "Error" state, try manually reprocessing it.

2. Use transaction SLG1: Look for logs under object /SCWM/QDECIDED_FUP_PROCESS to get more detailed error messages. This might reveal missing configuration or data inconsistencies.

3. Verify QIE configuration: Ensure that the Quality Inspection Engine (QIE) settings are correctly maintained, especially the follow-up action mapping.

4. Confirm RFC destination setup: The registered program /SPE/QUEUE_DISPLAY_TOOLS might not be correctly linked to the RFC destination. Check SM59 and transaction RZ70 to ensure the RFC destination is active and correctly configured.

5. Debug the queue manually: If the queue cannot be displayed, you may need to debug the function module /SCWM/QDECIDED_FUP_PROCESS directly to trace where it's failing.

Let me know if the issue still exist

entry.title: Re: KDM Transaction Key Not Triggering in Customizing Sys...
entry.content:
Hello @archana_raut38 

Thank you for your question.

If your MIRO is not posting did not generate KDM,  it is usually due to one some conditions not being met in the customising/test system.

Have a look at Material Account Determination , Evaluated Receipt Settlement (ERS) , SAP PRD and KDM Question for more details.

To summarise, in public cloud, the KDM transaction key is automatically triggered during MIRO only when an exchange rate difference arises between the Goods Receipt and the Invoice Posting for a foreign-currency PO. If KDM is not appearing in your test system, you will need to confirm a few details:

  • PO and MIRO are in different exchange rates.
  • Material has Price Control = V and zero stock at MIRO.
  • GR/IR is open at the time of MIRO.
  • KDM account is maintained correctly in Automatic Account Determination (SSCUI 100297).

You can test the following:

  • Create a PO in EUR with company currency IQD.
  • Post GR at one rate and MIRO at a higher/lower rate.
  • Check journal entry, a KDM P&L posting should be visible.

Once you have verified these, you can safely transport your corrected KDM account configuration to production.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Change Management in SAP migration processes
entry.content:
On 9 September 2025, Marta Mota spoke about migrating to SAP‚ÄØS/4HANA and emphasized the vital role of change management within such transformation programs. This event took place in the lectures that preceded SAP Inside Track Porto 2025.

The key points she covered include:

  • The migration to S/4HANA is not only a technical upgrade but a major business and organizational change. It affects processes, roles, and ways of working.

  • Successful migration depends on preparing people and organizational culture: ‚Äúthe human factor is often underestimated‚Äù when systems change. 

  • She highlighted the need to engage stakeholders early, including executives, business units, IT, and end users, to build shared vision and commitment.

  • Effective change management involves establishing a change network or champions within business units who can act as liaisons and multipliers for the transformation.

  • Clear, tailored communication is crucial: the changes should be explained in terms of what they mean for each team and individual‚Äînot just the IT system.

  • Training and adoption are not one-off tasks but ongoing journeys: users need not only to learn the new system but to adopt new behaviors and processes.

  • She underlined that it‚Äôs key to link the migration project to business value and concrete benefits for users, so that change is not perceived as purely disruptive but as enabling.

  • Among the risks she identified: insufficient readiness of the organization, lack of clarity in process change, and resistance from users who see the migration as a threat or overhead.

  • She pointed out that change management should be integrated into the migration roadmap ‚Äî not treated as a separate ‚Äúsoft‚Äù item but embedded in the project governance, timeline, and deliverables.

In short, migration to S/4HANA demands technical excellence, but equally the orchestration of people, process, culture, and change. Ensuring readiness, adopting change agents, and focusing on user adoption help the transformation deliver the expected value.

YouTube link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KsVZA1NoJjA

entry.title: Deleted Work Order and Position ‚Äì unable to reassign
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

A contingent worker was originally hired on a work order and position. Later, he became a regular employee and moved to another position.

The original work order was accidentally deleted, and the related position was also removed. Now I cannot recreate the work order or assign the same position back to the employee.

When I try, the system shows this error:

Error: It is not permitted due to your system configuration to process this transfer.
To perform the transfer, please terminate this record and then rehire with new employment.

What is the best way to restore the position and work order data back to this contingent worker?
I‚Äôm considering purging the CWK through DRTM and then recreating him as a contingent worker, but I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs possible to link the new CWK record back to his regular employee record afterward.

Thanks,
Sara
